channel.title: Learning Another Programming Language
channel.description:
Do you think it will be easier to learn a programming language after you have a pretty good grasp of another one and if so how much easier?
For example you know java pretty well and you want to learn C++

item.title: Learning Another Programming Language
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

AtomicInt_:

Java is to JavaScript as car is to carpet.

You said that backwards mate

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Another Programming Language
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Depending on what language you learned first. Usually, you will get the gist of a language that is quite similar to your well known language rather than a language that is completely unorthodox to it. An example would be learning C++ and trying to learn Ruby right after. You will have more struggle on Ruby than you would on Java if you had learned C++ first.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Another Programming Language
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

AtomicInt_:

Java is to JavaScript as car is to carpet.

This comparison would have been true before Chrome’s V8.

[quote=“greatpea, post:20, topic:543674”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=662556.msg4428427#msg4428427 date=1401990515]

Learn Java because it’s pretty much the same as JavaScript

Except for the fact they go about OOP entirely different.
[/quote]

is that all[/quote]

Other than prototypal vs classical OOP: JS is interpreted and Java is compiled, JS is single-threaded, JS is more functional in syntax (atleast before Java 8?), Java has static typing while JS is dynamically-typed, etc… The only thing that immediately comes to mind about Java and Javascript being similar is most of the basic language constructs and they both use a garbage collector lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Another Programming Language
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Truthfully, you’d be better off learning a language like C. But more importantly, you’d be better off learning the concepts behind programming, rather than focusing entirely on syntax. Once you’ve got a general grasp on certain concepts, it just becomes a matter of applying and remembering the syntax for different languages.

Obviously this isn’t ENTIRELY all there is too programming, given how different languages handle things like OOP, resource management, etc; so it’s a bit of general advice. Don’t focus too hard on particular language’s syntax, as opposed to the concept behind it.

Another thing to keep in mind, computer programming advice is kinda’ like discussing politics - everyone is going to have a different opinion, and usually if you don’t share the same opinion as someone else you’re wrong l0l

Read full topic

Learn Java because it’s pretty much the same as JavaScript

Wanna show me how?
[/quote]
java: a = b + c
javascript: a = b + c

It’s the same thing mate, don’t worry yourself.[/quote]

[code=JavaScript][/code]

[code=java]public class T {

public static int t(int val) {
    int x = 12;
    int y = 13;
    return x + y / val;
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
   t(4);
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Another Programming Language
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

If you know one programming language well and you have some knowledge about control flow in general (for computers using the von Neumann architecture), then learning a new programming language is a breeze. It’s practically just syntactic sugar. But if you want to master the new language (including potential best practices and libraries), you’d probably have to spend quite some time reading and practicing.

Read full topic
